title: How to Paint Your Front Door

steps.headline: Check with your homeowner’s association or landlord before painting.
steps.description: If you rent your house or apartment, or if you live in a location with a homeowner's association, there may be rules on what color your front door can be. Before painting, check in with any necessary authorities to make sure you aren't breaking any rules. If you paint your front door against your location's policy, you may have to re-paint it the original color.

steps.headline: Choose the impression you’d like your door to  make.
steps.description: Different colors convey different impressions. While colors like grey and blue can be calming, colors like red and yellow can be energizing. Decide what kind of impression you’d like to make on guests when they arrive and pick a color that conveys the energy you’d like your house to give off.

steps.headline: Take the other colors around the door into consideration.
steps.description: Think about the colors and scenery around you. What colors or shades would look particularly good with your garden, for instance? Or which shade would best compliment your house and fit in with the neighborhood? If you don’t have a strong color preference, considering how to match the colors around your door could help narrow down options.

steps.headline: See how different colors or shades look in the space.
steps.description: If you’re trying to choose between a few different paints, you can experiment with them. Paint a small piece of wood with one of your color samples. Then leave it by your front door and look at it at different times of day to see how the color looks in the space in different lights. Do this with multiple colors and choose whichever one you like best.

steps.headline: Remove the door from its hinges.
steps.description: Taking the door to a different work area will help you do the best job you can and also prevent unnecessary mess. You can paint the door while it’s on its hinges, but it will be more difficult to give it an even coat of paint because the paint will run and drip while you’re applying it. Make sure you have someone with you to help remove the door.

steps.headline: Move the door outside or to a well-ventilated area.
steps.description: Once it’s off its hinges, bring the door to a place you feel comfortable painting in, like a backyard. You won’t want to paint in an area where you could potentially get other valuables dirty. A basement work area can be a good option, but make sure it’s well-ventilated, as you don’t want to breathe in too many fumes from the paint. If you paint outside, check the weather beforehand. You don’t want rain to affect your paint job!

steps.headline: Set the door on sawhorses or old chairs.
steps.description: Lay the door horizontally across two sawhorses so that it’s level and parallel to the ground. If you don’t have sawhorses, you can use substitutes like old chairs. If you do use substitutes, just make sure it’s something you don’t mind getting dirty.

steps.headline: Place a drop cloth underneath the door to catch paint.
steps.description: This will prevent you from having to try to clean the ground or the floor after you’re done painting. Old blankets or table cloths that you’re not using anymore can work as substitutes if you don’t have a large canvas drop cloth.

steps.headline: Remove hardware like the door knocker, handle, and lockset.
steps.description: Make sure that you get paint only on the surface of the door. To prevent yourself from accidentally getting paint on anything else, remove the other parts of the door that come off. Door knockers and locksets should come off easily with a screwdriver.

steps.headline: Tape over pieces you can’t remove.
steps.description: Windows, for instance, very commonly can’t be easily removed from a door. Use blue painter’s tape to section off the edges of windows and anything else that can’t come off. This way you’ll only paint on tape if you cross over the edge of the area you’re working on. If you can’t remove the knocker, handle, and lockset, or just don’t have time to, you can tape around them as well.

steps.headline: Remove cracked or peeled paint with a putty knife.
steps.description: By removing any damaged paint from the old coat, you’ll help ensure that your new coat will go on smoothly. Work carefully so you don’t gouge the door or damage any other areas of the paint.

steps.headline: Smooth the door with sandpaper.
steps.description: Take a piece of fine-grit sandpaper and run it against the old coat of paint. Focus on areas that feel rough to the touch and sand them until they feel smooth under your fingertips. The smoother the door is, the easier it will be to apply your new paint evenly.

steps.headline: Wash the door with soapy water and let it dry.
steps.description: Fill a bucket with soapy water and grab a sponge. Use the soapy sponge to wash any dirt or debris from the door. This will help ensure that the surface of the door is as smooth as possible before putting on your new coat of paint.

steps.headline: Apply primer if the new color is significantly lighter than the old one.
steps.description: You don’t always have to use primer, but you should consider doing so if you think the old color will interfere with the new one. This can happen if the new color is much lighter than the old one. If you think you need it, apply one coat of primer to the door and let it dry. Primer generally takes about an hour to dry.

steps.headline: Stir paint before applying.
steps.description: When you buy your paint, make sure you pick up paint stirrers with it. Dip the stirrer into the paint and move it through until the color and consistency are as even as possible.

steps.headline: Use a brush on depressed panels and edges.
steps.description: Apply the paint in even strokes until each panel has an even coat of paint. Make sure to apply more paint to your brush periodically, so your strokes are spreading the paint in roughly equal amounts.

steps.headline: Use a paint roller for flat areas.
steps.description: Flat areas can be finished more quickly than recessed areas because you can simply roll the paint on. Pour some paint into a painting tray, and then move your roller through the paint. Roll the paint on evenly and apply more paint to it as needed.

steps.headline: Let the paint dry.
steps.description: It will usually take about 2 hours for paint to completely dry on a door. Place a small area of a rag against the paint to test whether or not it’s still wet. Check the area you painted last, as that will also finish drying last. Make sure it’s completely dry before moving on.

steps.headline: Apply a second coat for a better finish.
steps.description: Don’t worry if your door doesn’t look as great as you’d hoped yet. The second coat is often what really makes it stand out. Put on your second coat in the same way you did your first, being careful to apply the paint as evenly as possible.

steps.headline: Replace all the things you removed from the door.
steps.description: Your knocker, handle, and lockset can now go back on. Take off any blue painter’s tape that you applied to the door.

steps.headline: Reattach door and enjoy your new color.
steps.description: Once your second coat is dry, you’ll be ready to reattach your door and admire your handiwork. If you find that your new color isn’t working out as well as you thought it would, you can always put on a different color by following the same process. Otherwise, enjoy the new look of your front door!
